<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><Assets total="6" pageSize="2147483647" pageStart="0"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1011" id="Scope:1011"><Relation name="Parent" /><Attribute name="Parent.Name" /><Attribute name="Name">Company</Attribute></Asset><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1012" id="Scope:1012"><Relation name="Parent"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1011" idref="Scope:1011" /></Relation><Attribute name="Parent.Name">Company</Attribute><Attribute name="Name">Call Center</Attribute></Asset><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1013" id="Scope:1013"><Relation name="Parent"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1012" idref="Scope:1012" /></Relation><Attribute name="Parent.Name">Call Center</Attribute><Attribute name="Name">Release 1.0</Attribute></Asset><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1016" id="Scope:1016"><Relation name="Parent"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1012" idref="Scope:1012" /></Relation><Attribute name="Parent.Name">Call Center</Attribute><Attribute name="Name">Release 2.0</Attribute></Asset><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1017" id="Scope:1017"><Relation name="Parent"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1011" idref="Scope:1011" /></Relation><Attribute name="Parent.Name">Company</Attribute><Attribute name="Name">Corporate Website</Attribute></Asset><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1018" id="Scope:1018"><Relation name="Parent"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1011" idref="Scope:1011" /></Relation><Attribute name="Parent.Name">Company</Attribute><Attribute name="Name">IT Support</Attribute></Asset></Assets>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><Assets total="2" pageSize="2147483647" pageStart="0"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Task/1201" id="Task:1201"><Attribute name="Reference" /><Relation name="Owners"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Member/1000" idref="Member:1000" /></Relation><Attribute name="Owners.Nickname"><Value>AA</Value></Attribute><Relation name="Timebox"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Timebox/1025" idref="Timebox:1025" /></Relation><Attribute name="LastVersion" /><Attribute name="Source.Name">Planned</Attribute><Attribute name="ToDo">10</Attribute><Attribute name="Customer.Nickname" /><Attribute name="DetailEstimate">24</Attribute><Relation name="Scope"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1013" idref="Scope:1013" /></Relation><Attribute name="Parent.Name">Add Shipping Notes</Attribute><Relation name="Parent"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Story/1082" idref="Story:1082" /></Relation><Attribute name="Actuals.Value.@Sum">30</Attribute><Attribute name="Name">Service Changes</Attribute><Attribute name="Description"><P>Build a managed object context as an intelligent scratch pad. When you fetch objects from a persistent store, you bring temporary copies onto the scratch pad where they form an object graph (or a collection of object graphs). You can then modify those objects however you like. Unless you actually save those changes, however, the persistent store remains unaltered.<BR><BR>Objects that tie into the Core Data framework are known as <B>managed objects</B>. All managed objects must be registered with a managed object context. You add objects to the graph and remove objects from the graph using the context. The context tracks the changes you make, both to individual objects' attributes and to the relationships between objects. By tracking changes, the context is able to provide undo and redo support for you. It also ensures that if you change relationships between objects, the integrity of the object graph is maintained.</P></Attribute><Attribute name="Estimate" /><Relation name="Category"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/TaskCategory/112" idref="TaskCategory:112" /></Relation><Attribute name="Number">TK-01061</Attribute><Attribute name="Scope.Name">Release 1.0</Attribute><Relation name="Customer" /><Attribute name="Status.Name">In Progress</Attribute><Attribute name="Category.Name">Code</Attribute><Attribute name="Customer.Name" /><Attribute name="Timebox.Name">Month C 1st Half</Attribute><Relation name="Status"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/TaskStatus/123" idref="TaskStatus:123" /></Relation><Attribute name="Owners.Name"><Value>Andre Agile</Value></Attribute><Relation name="Source"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/TaskSource/157" idref="TaskSource:157" /></Relation></Asset><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Task/1208" id="Task:1208"><Attribute name="Reference" /><Relation name="Owners"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Member/1000" idref="Member:1000" /></Relation><Attribute name="Owners.Nickname"><Value>AA</Value></Attribute><Relation name="Timebox"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Timebox/1025" idref="Timebox:1025" /></Relation><Attribute name="LastVersion" /><Attribute name="Source.Name">Planned</Attribute><Attribute name="ToDo">24</Attribute><Attribute name="Customer.Nickname" /><Attribute name="DetailEstimate">24</Attribute><Relation name="Scope"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Scope/1013" idref="Scope:1013" /></Relation><Attribute name="Parent.Name">View Daily Call Count</Attribute><Relation name="Parent"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/Story/1083" idref="Story:1083" /></Relation><Attribute name="Actuals.Value.@Sum" /><Attribute name="Name">Service Changes</Attribute><Attribute name="Description"><P>Build a managed object context as an intelligent scratch pad. When you fetch objects from a persistent store, you bring temporary copies onto the scratch pad where they form an object graph (or a collection of object graphs). You can then modify those objects however you like. Unless you actually save those changes, however, the persistent store remains unaltered.<BR><BR>Objects that tie into the Core Data framework are known as <B>managed objects</B>. All managed objects must be registered with a managed object context. You add objects to the graph and remove objects from the graph using the context. The context tracks the changes you make, both to individual objects' attributes and to the relationships between objects. By tracking changes, the context is able to provide undo and redo support for you. It also ensures that if you change relationships between objects, the integrity of the object graph is maintained.</P></Attribute><Attribute name="Estimate" /><Relation name="Category"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/TaskCategory/112" idref="TaskCategory:112" /></Relation><Attribute name="Number">TK-01068</Attribute><Attribute name="Scope.Name">Release 1.0</Attribute><Relation name="Customer" /><Attribute name="Status.Name">In Progress</Attribute><Attribute name="Category.Name">Code</Attribute><Attribute name="Customer.Name" /><Attribute name="Timebox.Name">Month C 1st Half</Attribute><Relation name="Status"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/TaskStatus/123" idref="TaskStatus:123" /></Relation><Attribute name="Owners.Name"><Value>Andre Agile</Value></Attribute><Relation name="Source"><Asset href="/VersionOne/rest-1.v1/Data/TaskSource/157" idref="TaskSource:157" /></Relation></Asset></Assets>
